description: From Middle English reguler, from Anglo-Norman reguler, Middle French reguler, regulier, and their source, Latin rēgulāris (“continuing rules for guidance”), from rēgula (“rule”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *reg- (“move in a straight line”).

adjectives.description: regular (comparative more regular, superlative most regular)

entries.meaning: (Christianity) Bound by religious rule; belonging to a monastic or religious order (often as opposed to secular). [from 14th c.]
examples: regular clergy, in distinction from the secular clergy

entries.meaning: Having a constant pattern; showing evenness of form or appearance. [from 15th c.]
examples: Synonyms: equable, uniform, unvarying; see also Thesaurus:steady
Antonyms: chaotic, irregular; see also Thesaurus:unsteady

entries.meaning: (geometry, of a polygon) Both equilateral and equiangular; having all sides of the same length, and all (corresponding) angles of the same size [from 16th c.]
(geometry, of a polyhedron) Whose faces are all congruent regular polygons, equally inclined to each other.
Demonstrating a consistent set of rules; showing order, evenness of operation or occurrence. [from 16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: in order, ruly, tidy; see also Thesaurus:orderly
Antonyms: chaotic, tumultuous; see also Thesaurus:disorderly

entries.meaning: (astronomy) Of a moon or other satellite: following a relatively close and prograde orbit with little inclination or eccentricity.
(now rare) Well-behaved, orderly; restrained (of a lifestyle etc.). [from 16th c.]
examples: Synonyms: decent, seemly, well-mannered
Antonyms: degenerate, irregular

entries.meaning: Happening at constant (especially short) intervals. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: cyclical, frequent; see also Thesaurus:periodic
Antonyms: irregular, noncyclic
He made regular visits to go see his mother.

entries.meaning: (grammar, of a verb, plural, etc) Following a set or common pattern; according to the normal rules of a given language. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonym: (verbs) weak
Antonyms: irregular, (verbs) strong
"Walked" is the past tense of the regular verb "to walk".

entries.meaning: (chiefly US) Having the expected characteristics or appearances; normal, ordinary, standard. [from 17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: basic, common, unremarkable; see also Thesaurus:normal, Thesaurus:common
Antonyms: irregular, outlandish, weird; see also Thesaurus:strange

entries.meaning: (chiefly military) Permanently organised; being part of a set professional body of troops. [from 17th c.]
examples: Antonym: irregular

entries.meaning: Having bowel movements or menstrual periods at constant intervals in the expected way. [from 18th c.]
examples: Maintaining a high-fibre diet keeps you regular.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Exemplary; excellent example of; utter, downright. [from 18th c.]
examples: Synonyms: absolute, thorough, unalloyed; see also Thesaurus:total
a regular genius; a regular John Bull

entries.meaning: (botany, zoology) Having all the parts of the same kind alike in size and shape.
examples: a regular flower; a regular sea urchin

entries.meaning: (crystallography) Isometric.
(snowboarding) Riding with the left foot forward.
examples: Antonym: goofy

entries.meaning: (mathematical analysis, not comparable, of a Borel measure) Such that every set in its domain is both outer regular and inner regular.
(archaic, dialect, nonstandard) Regularly, on a regular basis.
examples: Though no minister would visit the Skerburnfoot, or, if he went, departed quicker than he came, the girl Ailie attended regular at the catechising at the mains of Sker.

entries.meaning: A member of the British Army (as opposed to a member of the Territorial Army or Reserve).
A frequent, routine visitor to an establishment.
examples: Bartenders usually know their regulars by name.

entries.meaning: A member of an armed forces or police force.
A frequent customer, client or business partner.
examples: This gentleman was one of the architect's regulars.

entries.meaning: (Canada) A coffee with one cream and one sugar.
Anything that is normal or standard.
examples: You separate the marbles by color until you have four groups, but then you notice that some of the marbles are regulars, some are shooters, and some are peewees.

entries.meaning: A member of a religious order who has taken the three ordinary vows.
A number for each year, giving, added to the concurrents, the number of the day of the week on which the Paschal full moon falls.
A fixed number for each month serving to ascertain the day of the week, or the age of the moon, on the first day of any month.
